pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Math Intensive Majors (MIMS) Project funded through the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) grant program awarded 166 scholarships over the course of the performance period, in the amount of $3,466 per student, per full-academic semester. The scholarship awards enabled underserved, financially disadvantaged students from backgrounds traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields, to invest more time and effort on their academic coursework and capacity development.  Student participants were provided with intensive mentoring and tutoring support, targeted exposure to STEM fields of study and career opportunities, and presentations by STEM professionals and representatives from four-year university STEM programs.  Project participants engaged in learning communities, developed collaborative projects and presentations, and also received training for, and participated in, peer tutoring and peer mentoring.  The MIMS Project met all of its proposed objectives, increasing the number of underserved and/or financially disadvantaged students pursuing programs of study and careers in mathematics, engineering and science, by improving access through scholarship awards; increasing the number of students declaring majors in STEM fields by over 57% by the end of the performance period through concerted advising; increasing retention and persistence through efforts such as mentoring, tutoring, and exposure to STEM degree programs and careers, with over 83% of project participants earning grades of "B" or better in their advanced mathematics coursework (Pre-Calculus; Calculus I; Calculus II; and Calculus III); and augmenting degree completion through transfer assistance efforts to four-year institutions of higher education.


Last Modified: 08/30/2016
Modified by: Claudia Verdin
